fullProgramDescription: The Mechanical Engineering program at UCLA provides a comprehensive education in the principles of mechanical engineering, including the design, analysis, and manufacturing of mechanical systems. The program emphasizes the development of problem-solving skills, creativity, and communication, preparing students for a wide range of careers in industry, government, and academia.
shortProgramDescription: The Mechanical Engineering B.S. program at UCLA provides a rigorous foundation in mechanical engineering principles, preparing students for diverse careers or further study.
classHighlights: The program begins with foundational courses in mathematics and physics, including Calculus, Differential Equations, and Physics for Engineers. These courses provide a solid base for understanding mechanical systems and principles.

Students then progress to core mechanical engineering courses, including Mechanics of Solids and Fluids, Thermodynamics, Heat Transfer, and Mechanical Design. These courses cover fundamental concepts and principles in mechanical engineering.
In addition to core courses, students take classes in mechanical engineering laboratories, where they gain hands-on experience with experimental techniques and data analysis.
The program also includes a range of technical electives, allowing students to explore specialized areas such as aerospace engineering, biomechanical engineering, or energy systems.
Throughout the program, students develop skills in computational tools, including programming languages and software packages commonly used in mechanical engineering.
The curriculum emphasizes the integration of theoretical knowledge with practical skills, preparing students for real-world applications in mechanical engineering.
learningOutcomes: Apply fundamental principles of mechanical engineering to analyze and design mechanical systems.
Demonstrate understanding of mathematical and scientific principles underlying mechanical engineering.
Use computational tools and experimental techniques to solve mechanical engineering problems.
Communicate technical information effectively through written and oral presentations.
Work effectively in teams to design and develop mechanical systems.
Understand the social and environmental implications of mechanical engineering practice.
additionalInformation: Students must complete a set of required courses in mechanical engineering, mathematics, and physics, as well as a range of technical electives. The program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
